channel.title: .class problems
channel.description: OK I don't know if i can put this here but i ruined all the .class files on my computer by making it so they open with notepad. I know how to make it so they open with other things but what do i open .class with? the image used to be like a black page.

item.title: .class problems
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

[quote=“noobface1234, post:8, topic:410797”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=512063.msg3716270#msg3716270 date=1313656292]

OK I don’t know if i can put this here but i ruined all the .class files on my computer by making it so they open with notepad. I know how to make it so they open with other things but what do i open .class with? the image used to be like a black page.

You can’t edit class files in a text editor. Class files are the result of compiling a Java source file, and hold the information about that source file in machine-readable language or “bytecode”.

Yea i know i can’t i didn’t mean to. But i need to change what i open it with back i think for it to work. so what do i make it open with? or can i just leave it alone?

On Windows, you can right click any class file, select “Choose default program…”, then from the list, select what you want to open it with, or if it’s not on the list, there is a “Browse” button for you to select the appropriate command from your system. Then, near the bottom-left, there is a small checkbox that says “Make this program the default program for opening this file type” or something similar.
[/quote]
what do i open it with though ?[/quote]

Nothing. Well, that’s not entirely true. I always suggest that people use the command prompt to navigate to their class files, and run it from there. The reason is because Java programs are started with the “java” program. For example, to run “Main.class” you would execute

java Main

However, in order for “java” to run a class file, it must have a

public static void main(String[] args)

method in it. Not all class files are required to have this however. Most classes often just represent data, such as an Item or an Npc.

Read full topic
